Award.AwardTitle: Integrating Directed Assembly and 3D Printing to Enable Advanced Nanomanufacturing Across Multiple Length Scales

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Access to nanomaterial building blocks with precisely controlled size, shape and composition has created a fertile opportunity space for emerging nanotechnologies. Prototype nanomaterial-enabled technologies spanning sensors, membranes, catalysis, data storage, electronics, displays, photovoltaics, energy storage, and thermoelectrics have generated high expectations for their commercialization. However, there is growing recognition that sustained progress towards the acclaimed promise of nanomaterial-enabled technologies depends critically on solving outstanding fabrication challenges; in particular the need to bridge the length-scale gap between millimeter scale devices and nanometer scale components. This research will develop spearheading nanomanufacturing capabilities to fabricate materials and devices with precisely programmed structure, composition, and function across six orders of magnitude in length scale. The research is driven by the vision that combined control over individual nanostructures (at atomistic length scales), programmable molecular assembly of micrometer superstructures and advanced manufacturing methods (spanning micrometer to meter) presents exciting prospects to manufacture new classes of materials and devices. Beyond the scientific and technological impact of advanced nanomanufacturing capabilities, the educational objectives of this project will focus research opportunities for undergraduates and minorities by developing interactive 3D printing learning modules.

The confluence of advances in directed assembly of nanomaterials and additive manufacturing technologies create powerful prospects to address critical challenges in scalable nanofabrication. On the one hand, technological applications of self-assembled nanostructures (e.g., nanoparticle superlattices) are limited by the lack of scalable fabrication methods. On the other hand, currently available 3D printing technologies are limited by speed, spatial resolution and material diversity. This project will explore synergies at the intersection of these two fields. The research team embraces the challenge of bridging this length scale gap as an opportunity to develop novel nanomanufacturing techniques that synergistically combine recent advances in molecular-level assembly and additive 3D printing. This project will explore the concept of continuous additive nanomanufacturing at Fluid Interfaces (CANFI). New knowledge from the project will establish the scientific and engineering foundation for advanced hierarchical nanomanufacturing techniques that span 6 orders of magnitude in length scale. Beyond the specific model systems at the focus of the work, the knowledge generated from this work is expected to have significant multiplying effects and will likely spur additional nanomanufacturing advances in related fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching objective of this project was to develop to develop nanomanufacturing capabilities that enable the production of materials and devices with precisely programmable structure, composition, and function across multiple length scales.

The vision driving the research is that combined control over individual nanostructures (at atomistic length scales), programmable molecular assembly of micrometer superstructures and advanced manufacturing methods (spanning micrometer to meter) presents an exciting, unprecedented and immensely fertile opportunity space to create a new class of materials and devices.

The key technological innovation and intellectual merit of the project was the synergistic integration of molecular scale self-assembly processes at the interface of two immiscible fluids with macroscopic digital light processing systems; the intellectual property associated with the continuous additive nanofabrication at fluid interfaces (CANFI) concept is protected by a provisional patent application. We have established the basic design principles and operating conditions of the CANFI printing process and developed the first known working curves (relating print layer thickness to photo dosage) printed at a liquid-liquid interface.  

We successfully demonstrated the proof-of-concept of this nanofabrication technique in the 3D printing of hierarchically porous architectures; this work was featured on the cover of Chemistry of Materials (see figure).  Inspired by complex 3D hierarchical mesoporous structures ubiquitous in nature, we demonstrated the fabrication of a 3D leaf including mesoscale pores for gas adsorption and macroscopic vasculature for transport of liquids. Whereas the 3D printed abiotic leaves lack the multifunctionality of natural leaves (i.e., fluid transport and photosynthesis); the ability to create programmable hierarchical porous materials defines an important step towards multifunctional devices.  

The diversity of chemical building blocks that can be used as ‘inks’ in the initial CANFI printing combined with the post-printing chemical functionalization opens up a broad range of opportunities. Beyond the zirconia clusters used in the initial proof-of-concept, we also demonstrated 3D printing with silica nanocages and colloidal semiconductor building blocks (see figures 3,4). Taking advantage of the internal porosity of the printed silica cages parts, we demonstrated a new internal 3D printing concept for the localized deposition of a guest material within a host matrix; this process enables the fabrication of complex 3D material designs not accessible otherwise. We foresee that this ‘internal 3D printing’ approach will have significant broader impact by enabling a number of novel device architectures with important potential for sensing, catalytic, or energy applications, which so far were not directly accessible with conventional material processing techniques.

As an initial proof-of-concept device structure that exploits the programmable porosity and chemical functionality we created monolithic mesoporous materials within the flow-channel of a microfluidic device and functionalized the high internal pore volume for specific biomolecule affinity. In combination, the ability to create structures with programmable porosity and chemical functionalization along with the ability to locally pattern electrodes opens up an exciting opportunity space for design, fabrication and testing of devices, for example biochemical diagnostics and separation.

This research program impacted the development of future scientists and engineers by inspiring and engaging them in emerging opportunities at the intersection of nanoparticle science and advanced additive manufacturing technologies. Training the workforce to seize opportunities at the confluence of advanced materials and fabrication methods creates is a critical component of revitalizing the U.S. manufacturing sector and ensuring global competitiveness in emerging markets. The graduate student supported by this grant is currently exploring entrepreneurial opportunities to bring the prospects of CANFI printing to technological fruition.

Beyond the science and technology aspects detailed above, results from this project have also had a broader societal impact. The CANFI printing process developed in this project serves as an advantageous example to intrigue and inspire future generations of scientists and engineers. This summer, we’ve presented the future prospects of printing capabilities enabled by the CANFI process as an analog to the ‘matter compiler’ described in Sci-Fi books like Neil Stephenson’s ‘The Diamond Age’. Whereas the ability to fabricate materials and devices with programmable hierarchical composition and structure is still in its infancy, these outreach events showcased our initial progress towards that ambitious objective and hopefully inspired future generations of scientists and engineers to join in this endeavor.

 


Last Modified: 12/27/2019
Modified by: Tobias Hanrath

Image
  • Inspired by the complex 3D hierarchical mesoporous structure ubiquitous in nature, this image shows how concurrent advances in nanomaterials chemistry and additive manufacturing can be integrated to create mesoporous inorganic leaf structures.(Chem. Mater. DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.9b02761)
    Tobias Hanrath
    Tobias Hanrath
    Three-Dimensional Printing of Hierarchical Porous Architectures
